questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
A user named User1 has a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10. Computer1 is joined to an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com. User1 joins Computer1 to contoso.com by using user1@contoso.com.
Computer1 contains a folder named Folder1. Folder1 is in drive C and is shared as Share1. Share1 has the permission shown in the following table.
//IMG//

A user named User2 has a computer named Computer2 that runs Windows 10. User2 joins Computer2 to contoso.com by using user2@contoso.com.
User2 attempts to access Share1 and receives the following error message: `The username or password is incorrect.`
You need to ensure that User2 can connect to Share1.
Solution: In Azure AD, you create a group named Group1 that contains User1 and User2. You grant Group1 Modify access to Folder1.
Does this meet the goal?

comments.content: The answer is clearly no..

Anthony, i always appreciate your analysis on the questions here, and you are 9/10 times right. But let's stand still for a moment for this question: there is nothing stated in the question about any on-premise AD, therefore you have to assume that this environment is simulated in an Azure (only) AD. In that case, assigning modify permissions for Folder1 to Group1, makes that the NTFS part is in place now to access Share1. Agree?
This answer couldn't be more incorrect, please stop spreading misinformation, correct answer is B

Just to amend your brilliant explanation. Azure AD synchronization has its limitation and it's one-way, from AD to Azure AD/Office365. There are only few attributes that can be written back, and that's mostly for Hybrid configurations, and passwords if you have the corresponding feature (and licenses) enabled. There is no built-in functionality that syncs users or permisions from Azure AD to on-premises AD.
Yes or no?
Thank you. :)
No. You can not edit share permissions through Azure AD.

I really don't see where you guys are getting these ideas about AAD Connect - there's nothing in this question to indicate a hybrid environment. I think this answer is No, I cannot see how you can add an Azure AD group to folder permissions - you can add a user, but am I wrong that you can't add a group?
Duyons is correct and my analysis needs to be reworked

This analysis is incorrect.
The process of Azure AD connect works only from on-premises to cloud. Whilst it is capable of things like password write back and device writeback, you cannot create users in Azure AD and sync them back to on-premises AD.

discussion.content: You need both security permissions (NTFS permissions) AND share permissions to view the contents of a shared folder. Change access is not a NTFS Permission. IT is a share permission. When the AZ AD syncs back to on premises AD the change access will not be implemented. Q21 identifies the solution by implementing the modify access which is a NTFS permission. Hence the answer is Yes

comments.content: This question confuses me how is Computer2 communicating with Azure AD? It is only joined to the on-prem AD and there is nothing indicating this environment is synced to Azure AD

discussion.content:
The answer is no!
You can´t add a group from azure AD on a joined machine, there´s no way to search on the directory like in an on-premise cenario

Selected Answer: B
No, this solution does not meet the goal.

The error message "The username or password is incorrect" indicates an authentication issue rather than a permissions issue. Creating a group and assigning permissions will not resolve the authentication problem.

To ensure that User2 can connect to Share1, you should verify the following:

Correct Credentials: Ensure that User2 is using the correct username and password to access Share1.
Network Connectivity: Confirm that Computer2 can reach Computer1 over the network.
Azure AD Join Status: Verify that both computers are properly joined to the Azure AD tenant and that User2's account is correctly synchronized.

Selected Answer: A
This seems more like an Azure question to me. But I think answer A is correct based on the article posted below. Using RBAC you can control NTFS permissions on a file. In my opinion this seems a little advanced for this exam, but it does appear to be doable. Also just an observation, usually the series of questions do have a correct answer from my experience. I rarely see them all be no. 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/files/storage-files-identity-ad-ds-configure-permissions

comments.content: This question must be related to the subject Azure File Share and it is implicit.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
YES

“You grant Group1 Modify access to Folder1” claim is an abstract claim that grants NTFS access to Group1 (created within Azure AD).

The question is right because it explains that there is NTFS permission (Modify) granted to the group.

Note the difference carefully:

*You grant Group1 Change access to Share1 - Grants Change via Share to Group1.
*You grant Group1 Modify access to Share1 - Grants Modify via NTFS for Group1.

Selected Answer: B
Answer is NO, AzureAD groups cannot be added to a local system as NTFS permissions.
User1,2 are joined to domain and they are in Group 1 which have Modify(NTFS) access to the folder1(share1). Seems YES is the anser. Azure AD sync direction (on-prem <> cloud) doesn't matter, does it?

If that one's right, that must be right, too.
Therefore, allergen B is correct.

Solution: In Azure AD, you create a group called Group1 that contains User1 and User2. You grant Group1 Change access to Share1.

Selected Answer: B
Refer to below link, we are not able to grant NTFS permission for Azure AD(not the hybrid environment). https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/43147/using-azure-ad-account-to-give-ntfs-level-permissi.html

Oh c'mon! This is the SAME question #7 from the previous page where the answer were NO, because "Azure AD cannot be used to control Share permissions on on-premisses computer folders". The only diference was the type of permission from "change" to "Modify".

comments.content: Reading the 2 questions with more attention I found the difference: In the question 7 from the previous page it says: "You grant Group1 Change access to Share1" and Azure cannot do that. But in this question it says: "You grant Group1 Modify access to Folder1". Meaning you locally change the permissions. Then the answer is YES. My bad, sorry guys.
When you go to the security tab (ntfs) of folder1 and try to edit and add Group1 (azureAD group) it won't show up !

discussion.content:
Acces to On-premises (AD) resources is only working when Windows Hello for Business is implemented with Key Trust Method: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/hello-hybrid-key-trust 

Default you cannot access on-premises resources with an Azure-AD account.
Is the final answer correct or is it No?

Essa questão ficou muito dividida no gabarito, afinal qual seria a resposta e qual a justificativa? Após um debate de 21 comentários, o gabarito é o mesmo ou não?

Answer is NO. The user has no permissions to Share1, only to Folder1.
In Azure AD, with group writeback enabled in AD Connect, you can create groups which will be synced back to the on-premise domain.
Modify is an NTFS permission unlike the previous change access which is a Share permission. It was explicitly added. An easy yes for me.

comments.content: Obviously I am voting for NO

discussion.content: So what is the correct answer?

comments.content: Guess you are allmost 2%right, keep up the good work of guessing ;-)
Whaha, you're so right. The renuka01 answer is worse than a fairytale.
adconnect is not only one way, but that doesnt matter as we do not use any sync in this question. we have two windows 10 computers and an azure ad nothing else...
Azure AD synchronization has its limitation and it's one-way, from AD to Azure AD/Office365. Duyons and myself agree on this. Check the analysis above. I still believe that the answer is wrong.

discussion.content: The answer is correct. The folder 1 is local, the share1 is in the cloud/network. Since Azure AD and on premises AD sync with each other, the Group1 in Azure AD syncs with the on premises AD. So the Group1 in Azure ID gets "modify rights" on Folder1 (which is local rights and thus applies for the NTFS rights). Summing it up, User1 and User2 are members of Group1 which has the NTFS rights. The NTFS rights is "modify" and the share permission is "Full control" allowing both users to change the files in the Share1.

I am voting for NO.
The process of Azure AD connect works only from on-premises to cloud. Whilst it is capable of things like password write back and device writeback, you cannot create users/groups in Azure AD and sync them back to on-premises AD.
Therefore, Group1 needs to be created in the on-premises AD instead of in Azure AD.

Microsoft could be testing for knowledge of this one-way sync.

To allow this user to access Azure Files, you must assign the share-level permissions to user2@contoso.com. The same concept applies to groups or service principals. Because of this, you must sync the users and groups from your AD DS to Azure AD using Azure AD Connect sync.

Share-level permissions must be assigned to the Azure AD identity representing the same user or group in your AD DS to support AD DS authentication to your Azure file share. Authentication and authorization against identities that only exist in Azure AD, such as Azure Managed Identities (MSIs), are not supported with AD DS authentication.

comments.content:
Additionally:
There are three Azure built-in roles for granting share-level permissions to users:

Storage File Data SMB Share Reader allows read access in Azure Storage file shares over SMB.
Storage File Data SMB Share Contributor allows read, write, and delete access in Azure Storage file shares over SMB.
Storage File Data SMB Share Elevated Contributor allows read, write, delete, and modify Windows ACLs in Azure Storage file shares over SMB.

You can use the Azure portal, Azure PowerShell, or Azure CLI to assign the built-in roles to the Azure AD identity of a user for granting share-level permissions.

Better Solution :
Create Group1 in on-premises AD. Add user1 and user2 to it and then it will sync to Azure AD
Add this to the NTFS permissions of Folder1.
From Azure AD assign the share permission : Storage File Data SMB Share Contributor role to user2@contoso.com.

Anthony,
There is nothing about AD on-premis in this question. There is only Azure AD. We don't have Azure AD Connect. You still think NO is the correct answer?

Exactly, there is nothing stated in the question about any on-premise AD, therefore you have to assume that this environment is simulated in an Azure (only) AD domain. In that case, assign Group1 to Folder1 with modify permissions, makes that the NTFS part is in place now to access Share1. Agree Anthony?

I think correct answer is YES. 
Users were created locally, there is talk about Groups.
Modify rights in available only under NTFS tab, thus I assume that user will receive appropriate rights to do it.

discussion.content: Agreed!

comments.content: To generate a report that contains all the Microsoft Edge policy settings applied to a computer, you can open the edge://policy page in Microsoft Edge. The edge://policy page provides a list of all the Microsoft Edge policy settings that are currently applied to the browser.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer A, running the Get-GPO cmdlet in PowerShell, is not applicable to Microsoft Edge policy settings, as it is used to retrieve information about Group Policy Objects (GPOs) in an Active Directory domain environment.

Answer B, running the Get-GPOReport cmdlet in PowerShell, is also not applicable to Microsoft Edge policy settings, as it is used to generate reports about GPOs in an Active Directory domain environment.

Answer D, opening the edge://settings page in Microsoft Edge, provides information about the browser's settings, but does not provide information about the policy settings that are applied to the browser.

Therefore, the correct answer is C. From Microsoft Edge, open edge://policy.

choices.A: From PowerShell, run the Get-GPO cmdlet.
choices.B: From PowerShell, run the Get-GPOReport cmdlet.

questions.answer_description:
The Get-GPOReport cmdlet would generate a report for all domain group policy objects. However, this would not display the settings that are applied by local group policy objects.
To display the settings applied by both domain and local GPOs, you would have to open Microsoft Edge and enter edge://policy in the address bar.
questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory domain. The domain contains 1,000 computers that run Windows 10.
You configure Microsoft Edge settings by using domain and local Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
You need to generate a report that contains all the Microsoft Edge policy settings applied to a computer.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Answer is correct 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/security-policy-settings/manage-auditing-and-security-log

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/security-policy-settings/interactive-logon-prompt-user-to-change-password-before-expiration

questions.answer_description:
User Rights Assignment > Manage auditing and security log.
Security Options > Interactive Logon: Prompt user to change password before expiration: 3 days.
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10.
You need to modify the Security Settings of Computer1 to meet the following requirements:
✑ A local group named Branch_Admins must be able to view and clear the Security log.
✑ Local users must be prompted to change their password three days before the password expires.
Which two nodes of the Local Group Policy Editor should you access to configure the settings? To answer, select the appropriate nodes in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Agreed

No, it is not possible to achieve the desired configuration by running the Microsoft Management Console (MMC) as User1 and adding the Group Policy Object Editor snap-in twice. The Group Policy Object Editor snap-in is used to manage and edit specific Group Policy Objects (GPOs), but it does not provide the capability to configure different group settings for different user groups.

wrng
njhj

choices.B: Run mmc as User1 and add the Group Policy Object Editor snap-in twice.
choices.D: Run mmc as User1 and add the Security Templates snap-in twice.
choices.C: Open Gpedit.msc as User1 and add two Administrative Templates.
choices.A: Use the runas command to open Gpedit.msc as each user.

questions.question_text:
You have a computer that runs Windows 10 Pro. The computer contains the users shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to use a local Group Policy Object (GPO) to configure one group of settings for all the members of the local Administrators group and another group of settings for all non-administrators.
What should you do?
questions.answer_description:
Add the Group Policy Object Editor snap-in twice. Select Browse > Users > Administrators when you add the first snap-in and select Browse > Users > Non-
Administrators when you add the second snap-in.

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory domain. The domain contains 1,000 computers that run Windows 10.
You configure Microsoft Edge settings by using domain and local Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
You need to generate a report that contains all the Microsoft Edge policy settings applied to a computer.
What should you do?
questions.answer_description:
The Get-GPOReport cmdlet would generate a report for all domain group policy objects. However, this would not display the settings that are applied by local group policy objects.
To display the settings applied by both domain and local GPOs, you would have to open Microsoft Edge and enter edge://policy in the address bar.

choices.B: From PowerShell, run the Get-GPOReport cmdlet.
choices.A: From PowerShell, run the Get-GPO cmdlet.
choices.D: From the Start menu, select Group Policy Object Editor.
